properties.name: Besi Shahar to Khudi
properties.description: A gentle start, Besi Shahar is one of the main start points for the trek and can be a good place to buy some supplies. From here to Khudi is an easy walk along the river (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/01/nepal-annapurna-circuitbesi-shahar-to.html).

properties.name: Khudi to Siarung
properties.description: Off the beaten track, this section takes you above the main Annapurna Circuit route to the village of Siurung (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/02/nepal-annapurna-circuitkhudi-to-siurung.html). Worth doing, the views over the river valley are great. This is an approximation of the route taken, not an exact track.

properties.name: Siarung
properties.description: A beautiful Nepali hill village with fine views of the surrounding countryside. Only one (small) guest house!

properties.name: Siarung to Jagat
properties.description: The descent from Siurung to Jagat (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/02/nepal-annapurna-circuitsiurung-to-jagat.html) takes you back to the main Annapurna route, but the first part is a beautiful walk in the higher part of the valley through a landscape of tiny settlements and rice fields. Once back on the main route the path becomes broader but the views are more restricted on the valley floor.

properties.name: Jagat
properties.description: A one-street village built above the river and surrounded by steep valley walls, Jagat has plenty of facilities for trekkers.

properties.name: Jagat to Dharapani
properties.description: Still following the river valley, the beautiful first part of this section (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/03/nepal-annapurna-circuitjagat-to.html) takes you up to the village of Tal where the river broadens out on what is said to have been the site of an ancient lake. From there the route goes to the village of Dharapani, surrounded by the high valley walls.

properties.name: Tal
properties.description: The small village of Tal is a good place to stop for lunch on the way to Dharapani. There is also accommodation here.

properties.name: Dharapani
properties.description: Dharapani is set in a stunning location in the narrow river valley, it has several hotels.

properties.name: Dharapani to Chame
properties.description: On this section of the route (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/03/nepal-annapurna-circuitdharapani-to.html) you start to feel that you are approaching the higher mountains, with views (if clear) of Annapurna 2 ahead and Manaslu behind. The route leaves the river for a while but returns once again for the walk into Chame.

properties.name: Chame
properties.description: The village of Chame is something of a regional centre, with more facilities than most other villages on the trek. You can change money here - at a worse rate than Kathmandu - and even connect to internet if you feel the need.

description.value: An easy day's walk (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/04/nepal-annapurna-circuitchame-to-lower.html) through pine woods and continuing to follow the course of the river valley. In between the villages of Bhratang and Dikhur Pokhari you can see (weather permitting) the massive rock face of Swargadwari Danda.

Lower Pisang is an interesting village to stop in with typical Tibetan style houses, and is just a short distance below it's neighbour of Upper Pisang. From the higher points you get impressive views bak down the valley.

Taking the high route above the valley floor and passing through the beautiful village of Ghyaru, this is a great day's walking (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/04/nepal-annapurna-circuitlower-pisang-to.html). With clear conditions you should get fantastic views of Annapurna 2 but even if the weather is not kind the detour is worth it.
One of the nicest villages on the entire circuit, it's a fairly tough climb to get here but well worth it.

Taking the high route above the valley floor and passing through the beautiful village of Ghyaru, this is a great day's walking (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/04/nepal-annapurna-circuitlower-pisang-to.html). With clear conditions you should get fantastic views of Annapurna 2 but even if the weather is not kind the detour is worth it.

properties.name: Braga (Bhraka)
properties.description: Lying a short distance from Manang this village is worth a stop to visit the centuries old monastery at the top.

properties.name: Manang
properties.description: Manang is a major stopping point on the Annapurna Circuit, and the last place of any size before crossing the Thorong La pass. A good place to do your acclimatisation (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/05/nepal-annapurna-circuitmanang.html) and enjoy the luxuries of coffee and apple pie.

properties.name: Manang to Thorung Phedi
properties.description: A 900 metre ascent from Manang to Thorung Phedi, the base for the route over the pass of Thorung La. The route is relatively easy (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/06/nepal-annapurna-circuitmanang-to.html) despite the altitude and for much of the way follows good paths. Letdar is a good place to stop on the way for a break.

properties.name: Thorung Phedi
properties.description: Thorung Phedi is located at an altitude of just under 4500 metres. You can stay here overnight before going over Thorung La pass. There is just a couple of places to stay and little else, although meals are available. Stock up on any luxuries in Manang. It can be very cold here at night, extra blankets may be available.

properties.name: Thorung Phedi to Muktinath
properties.description: The crossing of the Thorung La pass. Almost everyone sets off before dawn to do this crossing, as the day progresses it can get very windy up on the pass. From Thorung Phedi you have to ascend 900 metres to get to the pass. The first steeper part takes you up to the Base Camp, from there the ascent is gentler but longer. From Thorung La down to Muktinath is a descent of 1700 metres, and can be more difficult than going up in snowy conditions.

properties.name: Thorung Phedi to Muktinath
properties.description: The crossing of the Thorung La pass (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/06/nepal-annapurna-circuitthe-thorung-la.html). Almost everyone sets off before dawn to do this crossing, as the day progresses it can get very windy up on the pass. From Thorung Phedi you have to ascend 900 metres to get to the pass. The first steeper part takes you up to the Base Camp, from there the ascent is gentler but longer. From Thorung La down to Muktinath is a descent of 1700 metres, and can be more difficult than going up in snowy conditions.

properties.name: Thorung High Camp
properties.description: Located some 500 metres above Thorung Phedi, the High Camp is an alternative accommodation option and makes for a less arduous ascent up to Thorung La the next day.

properties.name: Thorung La Pass
properties.description: The highest point on the Annapurna Circuit at 5416 metres. If you are lucky you will get a cup of tea in the little refuge at the top before starting to descend. It can be bitterly cold here, especially if windy.

properties.name: Muktinath
properties.description: This village is located at 3700 metres and its temples make it a popular destination for both Hindu and Buddhist pilgrims. There are several hotels in the village and some not far beyond on the main track.

description.value: A long day's walk (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/08/nepal-annapurna-circuitmuktinath-to.html), but it's all downhill and the track for much of the way is easy. Spectacular scenery on the stretch down from Muktinath to Kagbeni. The village sof Jharkot and Kagbeni are both worth stopping in. From Kagbeni, the route follows the river valley downstream passing through the town of Jomsom and ending in the beautiful village of Marpha.

properties.name: Jharkot
properties.description: An alternative to Muktinath as a place to stay, Jharkot is about 20 minutes walk further down the hill. You can visit the monastery and enjoy the views from here.

properties.name: Kagbeni
properties.description: This village is the gateway to the Upper Mustang valley and is worth stopping in for a visit to the monastery or just to walk through the narrow, medieval streets.

description.value: A regional centre, Jomsom is not a pretty place but has more facilities than most places on the circuit. It's even possible to get here by air.

A pretty village of narrow streets and whitewashed stone houses, Marpha has plenty of places to stay and eat. The self.styled "apple capital of Nepal" also offers more or less every product associated with the fruit that you can think of.

An easy day (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/09/nepal-annapurna-circuitmarpha-to-ghasa.html), the path for much of the route is almost flat, at least until you get to Kalopani. The route follows the river valley through the villages of Tukuche, Kobani and Larjung. On one side is the Dhaulagiri range, on the other the Annapurnas. That's why it gets windy on thi stretch.

properties.name: Tukuche
properties.description: The first village you come to after Marpha, this is a pretty place in a broad stretch of the river valley.

description.value: Kalopani is one of the villages with most facilities for trekkers in this part of the route, although it's not the nicest place to stay. With luck you get a view of the peak of Annapurna 1 from here.

properties.name: Ghasa
properties.description: A small, attractive, village stretching down the valley. Surrounded by green hills with tumbling waterfalls. If you stay here try going up the road a bit early in the morning for a wonderful view of the Dhaulagiri.

description.value: Another gentle day's walking (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/09/nepal-annapurna-circuitghasa-to.html) down the river valley to Tatopani. It's possible to avoid the main road for a while by crossing the river shortly after Ghasa. The vegetation becomes much lusher on this section of the route, with rice fields and citrus trees reflecting the lower altitude and higher temperature.

properties.name: Dana
properties.description: This is a small village which makes a good stopping place for lunch in pleasant surroundings.

properties.name: Tatopani
properties.description: Tatopani is famous for its hot springs, although they left me underwhelmed. The village is set in attractive surroundings by the river, and has some nice hotels and restaurants. A pleasant place to stop.

description.value: Get ready to climb again. The route to Ghorepani (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/11/nepal-annapurna-circuittatopani-to.html) takes you up approximately 1700 metres from Tatopani. It's a beautiful walk with wonderful views over the valley and the track is in good condition - many sections are paved and stepped. As you get higher above the village of Shikha you enter the rhododendron forest that covers the higher slopes around Ghorepani.

properties.name: Shikha
properties.description: This is an attractive village about half way between Tatopani and Ghorepani. A good place to have lunch. Keep an eye out for houses with tree trunk beehives attached to the facade.

properties.name: Chitre
properties.description: Last stop before Ghorepani, not far to go now although the path through the forest gets steeper.

properties.name: Ghorepani
properties.description: Ghorepani is a touristy place with plentiful hotels because of its proximity to Poon Hill. The village itself is not very lovely and can be very cold at night. But the location is stunning.

description.value: Walkers get up early to climb Poon Hill (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/11/nepal-annapurna-circuitpoon-hill.html), a magnificent view point for seeing the Dhaulagiri range, the southern side of the Annapurna's and the sacred mountain Machapuchare. Try to get there before sunrise if the weather is clear, it takes about 45 minutes to climb from Ghorepani.

properties.name: Ghorepani to Tikhedunga
properties.description: Time to go downhill again, the first part of the descent from Ghorepani (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/12/nepal-annapurna-circuitghorepani-to.html) is a beautiful walk down through the rhododendron forest. Near to the village of Ulleri the forest clears to give views of the the surrounding countryside. Much of the path at this point consists of steps, so although not long the route can be quite tiring.

properties.name: Ulleri
properties.description: A good point to have a break and maybe something to eat, this is the last village before Tikhedunga and has excellent views of the valley below.

description.value: Tikhedunga doesn't seem like much when viewed from the route above, but it is a small and pleasant place to stay.

The last section of the trek (http://southofwatford.blogspot.com/2010/12/nepal-annapurna-circuittikhedunga-to.html), a relatively easy and short (around 3 hours) stretch. The enjoyable walk takes you through the village of Birethanti (also access point for Annapurna Base Camp) and then up to the main road at Nayapul from where it's possible to get transport to Pokhara.

properties.name: Birethanti
properties.description: Birethanti is a busy village because it lies on both the Annapurna Circuit track and on the alternative trek that goes to the Annapurna Base Camp. Birethanti is just a short walk from the main road.

description.value: Nayapul is really just the point where you either begin or end the trek. This is where the trek connects to the road that goes to Pokhara. To stay somewhere nicer it would be better to stop at Birethanti, which isn't far away.
